bibl.title: Military Orders for Walter Reed, October 28, 1898

div1.p: Reed's letter and Sternberg's endorsement suggest that Natural Bridge, Virginia, is not a suitable location for an army hospital due to the condition of the buildings and transportation issues. The documents are dated October 28, 1898 and October 30, 1898. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

Report of Inspection of Build-
ings at Natural Bridge, Va.
for hospital purposes.
Filed with 143204. A.G.O.

FILE.
DEC 20 1898
[UNCLEAR]
143204

1st INDORSEMENT
WAR DEPARTMENT,
Surgeon Generl's Office.
October 30th, 1898.

Respectfully forwarded to the
ADJUTANT GENERAL OF THE ARMY. The
locality referred to in this report
would be favorable so far as climate
and other local conditions are con-
cerned, but the buildings now upon
the land are not suitable for hos-
pital purposes. In my opinion a
locality upon the sea-board as far
north. as New York would be a better
location for a general hospital in
view of the fact that the sick from
Cuba and Porto Rico could be brought
to such a hospital by our hospital
ships without being subjected to the
hardships of railroad transportation.

G. M.Sternberg
Surgeon General, U. S. Army.

Filed by a.g.o.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to the Surgeon General, October 28, 1898
div1.opener:
All communications to this Office should be addressed “To the Surgeon General, U. S. Army, Washington, D. C.”
Subject: Inspection of buildings at Natural Bridge, Va.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
U. S. ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
Corner 7th and B Streets S. W.,
Washington, October 28, 1898., 189 .
TO THE SURGEON GENERAL,
U. S. Army.
Sir:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report that in compliance with S.O., No. 247,
Par. 80, Headquarters of the Army, A.G.O., Washington, October 19, 1898,
I visited Natural Bridge, Va. on Oct. 22, 1898, and made a careful in-
spection on the 24th and 25th insts. of the several buildings located
at that point, inquiring also, into the character of the water supply,
in accordance with verbal instructions received from the Surgeon General.

As a result of my inspection, I beg to report as follows: Natural
Bridge (altitude 1500 ft.) is distant about three miles from Natural Bridge
station, which is situated at the junction of the Shenandoah Valley Div-
ision of the Norfolk and Western Rail Road; and the James River Division
of the Chesapeake and Ohio R.R.

The following buildings were examined: 1. The Appledore Hotel, a 3 sto-
ry frame building, weather boarded without, lathed and plastered within,
with slate roof, and containing 44 rooms. This building, which is in
good repair, faces South-east, each story being provided with a veranda
front and rear, and on the South end. The width of the veranda in front
(2)
is 10′ - on the rear and South end 6′ 3″. The height of stories is as
follows: 1st story 10′, 2nd and 3rd, each 8′ 7″. The 1st story has 16
rooms, as follows: one room (office) 17′ × 23″ communicating with dining
room 23′ × 14 1/2′, and 14 rooms, each 14″ × 9′ 6″, convertible into suites
of 2 rooms, by communicating door. The office and dining room and 4 of
the smaller rooms are heated by open fire-places. The remaining 10 rooms
have no means for heating.

The 2nd story has 16 rooms as follows: A front parlor 17′6″ × 17′6″:
a rear parlor 17′8″ × 13′, and 14 rooms 14′ × 9′6″, convertible into suites
of 2 rooms by communicating door. Six of these rooms have open fire-places,
the others no means of heating.

The 3rd story has 12 rooms as follows: one room 17′6″ × 17′6″; one room
17′6″ × 13′ and 10 rooms 14′ × 9′6″, convertible into suites of 2 rooms by
communicating doors. Six of these rooms have open fire-places.

The upper stories of the building are reached by a stair-way having a
width of 4′1″- width of hall on each floor 4′6″.

All rooms are lighted and ventilated by one or more sash-doors with
transom. Each story is provided with a water-closet and bath_tub, a
small room 6′ × 7′6″ having been partitioned off on each rear veranda for
this purpose. The water-closets are provided with flushing tanks and have
only recently been placed in position. These closets are drained into a
4″ iron pipe which connects with a tile pipe passing beneath the building
and emptying into a small creek, about 500 yards distant. As far as I
could ascertain, the plumbing arrangements were satisfactory, but there is
no means provided for heating the bath rooms, nor any measures taken to
(3)
prevent water pipes from freezing. 2. Adjoining this building on its
North end and attached to it is an unfinished 3 story frame building,
with attic, which was begun about five (5) years ago. It was not possi-
ble to form any idea as to the interior of this structure, as there was
simply the frame work with roof, but without flooring, stair-ways, plas-
tering &c.

3. Pavilion Hotel, a frame building, 2 stories in height, situated on a
lower level than the Appledore Hotel, and about 45 yards distant. The
entire first story consists of a dining room 78′ × 27′ × 12′. This room
has no windows, but is lighted by large, double, sliding sash-doors on both
sides and ends. There is no provision for heating or ventilation. The
second story is divided into 14 small rooms, each 12′6″ × 14′, height of
ceiling 10′6″. These rooms are situated on either side of a hall 4′ in
width, and each have one window and one door.

Each story has a veranda 10′ in width, on all sides. The building is
supported on brick piers, about 7′6″ in height, enclosed with a lattice-
work. A temporary kitchen has been fitted up underneath the North end of
the building.

4. Private residence of Mrs. Parsons. This building, distant about 70
yards from the main hotel, is a 2 story frame dwelling with attic and
basement. Height of 1st & 2nd stories 7′6″. There are 22 rooms of various
sizes, the majority being quite small.

In addition to the buildings already mentioned, there is a frame cottage
of 7 rooms, situated about 100 yards from the hotels.

The several buildings are located on hill-sides, which insure perfect
drainage.

The water-supply for the Appledore hotel is obtained by means of a
2′ pipe, from a spring about 1 1/4 miles distant, and quite remote from any
source of contamination. Its pressure is sufficient to carry it to any
part of the building. I visited this spring and ascertained from inspection
that approximately, one half of its flow is being used at present.

The Pavilion hotel is supplied from a very large spring, about 100 yards
distant, the water being delivered by means of its own pressure.

As the result of my inspection, I am of the opinion that although an
abundant supply of pure water could be easily obtained, none of the
buildings located at Natural Bridge, Va. are suitable for hospital purposes;
the rooms, with few exceptions; being quite small, and ceilings low. An-
other objection to its selection for a hospital site is the distance from
the Rail Road, viz:-three miles. An ordinary country road, rather rough
in places, leads from the station to Natural Bridge. The latter is at an
elevation of about 400 feet above the Rail Road, so that there is a grad-
ual ascent for a greater part of the way.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully, Walter Reed, Major & Surgeon,
U. S. Army.
